I get this urge too. If Iâ€™m at home or somewhere else I can give into it, I will just stop and sit down. Sometimes in weird places too. And, like you say, I just detach from the world or kind of retreat inside myself? If Iâ€™m not interrupted I can lose hours this way. Then once I come out of it, Iâ€™ll have no memory of what I was thinking about, but this incredibly intense nagging of wanting to remember, like when you wake up after a dream. 

If Iâ€™m somewhere I canâ€™t just stop, it takes all my focus and energy to push myself to keep moving, and I feel overly drained and exhausted.

I get concerned about laziness too because sometimes this causes me to not get things done I need to. But itâ€™s definitely not by choice.

I've been taking Zyrtec everyday during the Spring for years without incident. But I've had some weird experiences with Benadryl. I never had any idea  it had something to do with BP.

This past year I finally got better about cooking for myself and wasting less food and money. There are lots of videos on YouTube about cooking on a budget, even with bulk cooking at the beginning of the week. I'd start there and use a premade shopping list at first so you can start to see how to use foods in different recipes. That way you aren't eating the same thing over and over. I had to meal plan every week for a while. But now that I've gotten used to it,  I don't have to plan it all out anymore, I'm just mindful of buying foods I can use in different ways.
I stopped going because I always felt so shamed by them. I have terrible teeth, but haven't been in years.

I think what you wrote is awesome, and most people would sympathize and 'get it.' That would be really courageous to send, and think of how much lighter you'll feel both facing it and getting to go back. I say go for it! I had to send something similar to my excoworkers, but struggled to be so open and honest. Even so, they all were so loving and sweet about it. I really missed them too, so it meant a lot to me.

I am also a people pleaser, and that's exactly what happened to me recently. They kept piling things on me, and as a perfectionist too I would push myself harder and harder to make them exactly what they wanted. I'm really artistic and a good designer, and people always seem to take advantage of me, my talent and my niceness. I have a constant list of things people have asked me to design for them as favors.  The problem is that I actually deliver when I'm manic, which makes people keep asking. Until I just break and crumble under the weight of it all and disappear. It's a terrible way to live.
Ugh this always pops into my head, especially when I'm feeling hopeful and positive. I think, "Really, what's the point? I won't even be here.

I have ghosted people in literally every single way as you (even the green organization I used to volunteer for and a clay throwing class that I sucked at haha.)  I almost always regret it, then feel like too much time has passed since I answered, so then i feel like I need to avoid them for the rest of my life. It's awful, and I feel so mean and callous sometimes.

Thank you so much for this advice. I just blew up my life and ruined my career and have been hiding in my house trying to reenter the world for the last 2 months. The feeling of guilt and hatred for myself keep pulling me back every time I start to feel hopeful. Going to work on acceptance.
Thank you so much for posting this.
I love your mom. Can we trade?

Thank you so much for this advice, I find the self-loathing so hard to deal with. I leave most social situations berating myself for always making it weird and I bully myself over it for hours/days/weeks.

I hope you are making it through your party and are feeling a teensy bit better now. I have to move when I'm that anxious, and cold really helps. Sometimes I literally stick my head in the freezer and just breathe lol.

I  would love both sending or receiving that text.  Especially with new flings, where for me every response is stressful. I wish everyone was so clear and upfront. Also, I need a lot of space in a relationship (and for my SO not to get offended or read into that need) so I think setting clear boundaries so early on is really awesome.

I have done this too many times to count with friends and also with work. I push them away when they get too close because I don't want them to see what a mess I am. But then I feel desperately lonely.

So sorry to hear about your friends. I've also lost many friendships. It's been hard because I've only just been diagnosed and didn't have a way to explain myself. I would just look back at the destruction and retreat and hide. I've ghosted/avoided a lot of people in the last decade.

I realized I was goofily smiling by the time I got to the end of your post because I think you're adorable. It sounds to me like you two are falling in love, but maybe I'm just being a hopeless romantic. 

As someone who stopped dating for many years due to depression, I'd say give him a chance.  Take it slow, and he may need you to make a move every now and then. I recently dated a guy with anxiety who thanked me so much for  initiating the 4th date because he was feeling nervous I was just going along to be kind.
Beautiful. I love everything about snow storms. This both captures the quiet space of snow, and so calmly explains the exhausting stream of thoughts. I really love it.
It's beautiful, I love it. I have a tattoo on my arm as a visual reminder to help see me through. Best decision I ever made, it feels like such a part of me. I hope yours comes to feel like that too!

Thanks, fixed!

I love this and totally agree with you. I actually already have a pretty solid idea for a program that would allow teachers to easily customize for a class of any size with about 30 different options for student materials, equaling hundreds of different ways to customize. I'm thinking for use in moderate to high special and any gen ed/inclusion class.) 

Teachers would enter their class roster and either fill out a short survey for every student or give a super short assessment to each student (ideally there would be a technology tie in so maybe online.) 

Then the program would automatatically customize student materials for every lesson. Maybe print 10 lessons at a time, then go back and change options as needed. Is the student extremely slow or do they rush? Less questions? Higher level questions and more of them for gifted students? they able to read(at what level?) or does everything need to be in pictures? Can they write independently, do they need to trace or should everything be picture based? Dyslexia font? Large text/small text/space... you get the idea. 

Ideally this would all be tied in with UDL strategies and students would be moving/acting and interacting as parts of every lesson. I envision lots of hands on materials that are ALREADY MADE and well organized so it is extremely easy to set up for every lesson. Maybe the program could even come up with ideal student groupings based on abilities (with personality input available because everything should be customizable.) I would ,over it to also include materials for leveled independent centers.

The program could possibly even customize the lessons for each class makeup. Change the delivery/length/number of breaks/ primary learning style etc. Nonverbal/talkative/antsy? Change it up. Maybe even offer a scripted or non scripted version for teacher preference. 

There would definitely be a slide show component that has picture/visual instructions and keeps students together and also allows the teachers to follow along as they teach. 

I really think this sort of program would help in cities like mine where over 70 percent of our students are 2 or more grade levels behind by 3rd grade. The curriculum just isn't reaching them and there is way too much for teachers to do. They ask for data-driven modifications but don't give us the tools/time for it all.
I have also done this, which is crazy.
Thanks so much, I used to love to write but never showed anyone, so this means a lot!

Ugh I feel like I have to chime in to defend the vegans here lol. I will happily date people who eat whatever. I've been vegan/veg a loooonngg time though and did not feel this way at first, so I could totally see it being a deal breaker if you meet someone who doesn't respect that you're eating meat. 

I also live in a largish city that has a HUGE vegan population, so there is literally at least one vegan option at 95% of the restaurants here, so I can easily and happily share food experiences with guys. If they make the plans I tell them not to even think about it.

My ex and I used to go to this one place all the time where we both loved getting drinks and the vegan buffalo wings app, but then I'd get a vegan entree and he'd have a bacon cheeseburger. I just don't think you should totally avoid vegan because you think it will be too hard. Even TGIFridays has a vegan burger lol
